instruction: What is the purpose of the Sentinel-2-based NRT change detection system in monitoring forest cover loss in Mexico and Colombia?
Output: The purpose of the Sentinel-2-based NRT change detection system in monitoring forest cover loss in Mexico and Colombia is to provide near real-time alerts and monitoring of natural and anthropogenic disturbances in the forests. It enables forest landowners, government agencies, and local communities to have more up-to-date forest inventories and allows for rapid responses to unlicensed logging. The system uses operational Earth observation data from the Copernicus Sentinel-2 satellites, providing multi-spectral optical/near-infrared wavelengths every five days at a global scale and 10 m resolution. The system is designed to accurately detect forest cover loss, other vegetation loss, and other vegetation gain, and can be scaled up to larger regions, entire countries, and even continents.

instruction: Can the proposed Sentinel-2-based NRT change detection system using spectroscopic methods be considered superior to traditional methods in accurately detecting forest cover loss and other vegetation changes in Mexico and Colombia?
Output: Yes, the proposed Sentinel-2-based NRT change detection system using spectroscopic methods can be considered superior to traditional methods in accurately detecting forest cover loss and other vegetation changes in Mexico and Colombia. The system utilizes near real-time change detection of forest cover loss, which allows for more timely monitoring of disturbances compared to traditional thematic maps released annually. The system also relies on operational Earth observation data from the Copernicus Sentinel-2 satellites, providing high-resolution multi-spectral optical/near-infrared data every five days at a global scale. This frequent and detailed data acquisition enables more accurate detection of forest cover loss, other vegetation loss, and other vegetation gain. An independent validation using very high-resolution PlanetScope and RapidEye data suggests that the proposed system can accurately detect forest cover loss (> 87%), other vegetation loss (> 76%), and other vegetation gain (> 71%). Additionally, the system is designed to be scalable to larger regions, entire countries, and even continents, making it a valuable tool for monitoring forest and vegetation changes in Mexico, Colombia, and beyond.
